title: The Pirate Planet
dialogue_triumphs: The Doctor is asked what he does for a living: 'I save planets, mostly.'
The Doctor explains to Romana how he arrived at a deduction: 'I just put 1.795379 and 2.20468 together.' 'What does that mean?' 'Four!' (4.000059, actually.)

continuity_notes.name: Romana
continuity_notes.description: Time Lord companion of the Doctor
continuity_notes.current_status: Traveling with the Doctor, shows surprising accuracy with shooting

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time and space machine
continuity_notes.current_status: Operated by the Doctor for 523 years, not indestructible

continuity_notes.name: Gallifreyan Academy
continuity_notes.current_status: Offers optional courses on 'veteran and vintage vehicles' and 'life-cycle of the Gallifreyan flutterwing'

continuity_notes.name: Calufrax
continuity_notes.current_status: Rich in voolium and madranite one-five, second segment of the Key to Time

roots: Through the Looking Glass (the inertia-free walkway)
Beach Boys ('You mean they pinned him to the wall with Good Vibrations?')
Monty Python's Flying Circus (allusions to 'The Spanish Inquisition' and a dead parrot)
The Hitch Hiker's Guide to the Galaxy
links: The unconscious Doctor mumbles 'no more janis thorns' (a reference to Leela)

locations.name: Zanak
locations.description: Planet where the main action takes place
locations.current_status: Under the rule of the Captain, pirating other planets

untold_adventures: The Doctor told Sir Isaac Newton the idea for gravity at dinner after sitting in his tree dropping apples on his head
additional_notes: The Doctor lies to the Captain, telling him that the TARDIS has a lock that requires both his and Romana's presence when being opened.
bottom_line: An inventive story, 'The Pirate Planet' has matured into a satisfying mixture of the clever and the absurd. There are Hitch Hikers in-jokes aplenty and a sense of a cast having great fun with a script.
